course_title: Sem:Ancient Mediterr/Anatolian Art: Conc/Exp.of Images Anc.Egypt
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 8 / Seats Avail: 5Waitlist Total: 0
class_notes:
Complete Topic - Conceptions and Experiences of Images in Ancient Egypt
Images in ancient Egypt were ubiquitous and used for a wide variety of purposes, perhaps most famously hieroglyphic writing, reliefs and paintings on the walls of temples and tombs, as well as cultic and monumental statues. Drawing on different types of ancient sources as well as theoretical discussions from Egyptology and beyond, this course explores the various ways in which the relationship between an image and that which it depicts could be understood and utilized, covering the full cycle of attested practices of planning, making, using, altering, and destroying images.
This is an upper-level, writing-intensive seminar designed for students who have some experience with art history, typically having taken courses at the 200 or 300 level.
Art History major/minor: Division I
course_description: Advanced seminar with emphasis on critical texts, methods, and techniques of art historical investigation. For art history majors; open to others with permission from the instructor.
sections: Class Nbr: 1906, Section #: 1, Type: SEM, Campus: ATL, Meets: F 1-3:45p, Instructor: R. Nyord, Status: Open
